title: Which soccer/football club will win the 2019-20 UEFA Champions League?
preds: Bayern is strong everywhere. PSG is strong on offense
Bayern have momentum working on their side as well as confidence. PSG have Neymar! Also, Lyon showed that you can get behind Bayern's high defensive line and make scoring chances.
Bayern should win but may have peaked too soon with two good games?

Munich are red hot favorites, having scored 43 goals, but PSG have the tournament's best defense, conceding just 5 goals. Football is a game of variance and the superior side does well to create a high scoring game allows its qualities to shine through, whereas the inferior side does better by closing down the game, increasing its chances of an upset. In that frame, I expect Hansi Flick to attack, though I am not sure he will play as high a line as he did against Barcelona and Lyon, so Munich, the superior side, should be favorites. PSG's success depends on how successfully they can close the game out, which means playing against type and playing with a low block and a hoping Di Maria, Mbappe & Neymar can take advantage of the gaps Munich will leave. PSG's threat on the counter combined with their defensive grit will be key for their success. If PSG win, they will win I think in a tight, suffocating game. Nevertheless, as I said, I think Munich can make the game open and win. My one source of unease is that Munich have been so good they may be due a check...

BM must be favourites but their defence is not the best and PSG have a formidable attack, but then again so do BM. PSG are the glamour side but BM are very focussed and determined and destroyed Barcelona. BM have to start as strong favourites.
Taking 538 prediction as baseforecast which is 64% Bayern - but pushing up further as I rate experience with big games in European settings (on club & individual levels) as a material determinant

I thought a lot about the final game, and I decided to favor Paris SG this time for a couple of reasons:
/FC Bayern München has again been very lucky not having a goal against them. Their statistics look more perfect than they are, in fact Olympic Lyon missed a few golden opportunities early, so the match could easily have ended 4  -  4 (or 2  -  2) after 90 minutes. FCB has counted on luck too much too long, a luck they will maybe not be provided with once again in the final game.
/FCB started with the same initial team for three matches in a row, which is reasonable when there's nothing to complain about. However, three and a half days in tournament mode are very little time to recover fully physically (everyone who has ever tried a marathon will know what I'm talking about). Even if the team has the best physical practitioners in the Bundesliga, key players such as Lewandowski, Kimmich, Müller may become increasingly tired and worn, concerning their age, and will not be able to play to their full potential on Sunday. Again, FCB was lucky that Gnabry did the scoring this time.
/In contrast, Paris SG has key players such as Mbappé, who have played joker roles for up to 30 minutes per game, who I assume are fresh and eager to win.
/FCB has been assigned the role of the favorite team for the whole Lisbon tournament, which is a tricky position for individual psychology. On the one hand, if you as a player believe it, you will be levitating too much and the tension necessary to master a final will be gone and the team may be caught in a trap. If you do not believe it, you might start to mull the possibility to screw the game up, some of the individuals playing with unease will weaken the team. Even if the coach of FCB and players stress at every opportunity that they take PSG very seriously and it will not be an easy game, it's a very fine line between fighting self-conceit and hubris on the one hand, and fighting self-doubt and wariness on the other hand before the match to remain stable and in balance as a team in the match. There is too much at stake and too much to lose for FC Bayern München to go easy. PSG has the far easier part in this for the next four days. AND: Paris SG now has the coach who FC Bayern München has always tried to hire and who is now contracted happily in Paris. He knows Bundesliga football precisely from his stages at
2009–2014 	1. FSV Mainz 05
2015–2017 	Borussia Dortmund
and the tactics of FC Bayern München by heart. PSG will be better prepared than any other UEFA CL team meeting FCB before.
However, I'm not surprised if FCB will win anyway, and they will probably have earned it.
Final is Bayern PSG and Bayern are definitely the favorites.

I give PSG a chance because BM concede chances, but I suspect BM will score more.

PSG whilst improving and Neymar seems to have a CR7 2016 Euros will to win the competition on his own vibe I still think this is Bayern's to lose.

This is an update to my previous forecast. In the 2019-20 UEFA Champions League, the remaining teams are Bayern Munich (BYM), Paris Saint Germain (PSG), RB Leipzig (RBL) and Lyon (LYN) ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_UEFA_Champions_League#Semi-finals  Of the four remaining teams, only BYM has ever been in the Final of the UEFA Champions League before ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League#Performances_by_club  From the 1957-2019 Champions League Finals, I counted 14 times when the Winner hadn't been in a UEFA Champions League Final before e.g. 1977, 1997->
Champions League Winner in 2020 hasn't been in a Final before = 22% = 14 / (2019 - 1957 + 1) Given both PSG and LYN have more experience in the Knockout stage of the Champions League than RBL I will give them the majority of the 22% ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League_clubs_performance_comparison BYM = 78% = 100% - 22%
PSG = 9%
LYN = 11%
RBL = 2% If LYN beats BYM in the Semifinal I will revise my prediction but I believe this to be highly unlikely given their surprising win over Manchester City is being blamed by football commentators on City's Manager ->
https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/53794738

RB Leipzig vs Paris SG: 2  -  0
Olympique Lyon vs FC Bayern München: 3  -  1 If both teams under "Another soccer/football club" win their semi-final by Wednesday night, the question will be immediately resolved even ahead of the final, so there will be no time to adapt.
My forecast is against all odds, especially when it comes to FCB, but OL have proven they can hurt even top ranked teams. I would not be surprised, if OL - FCB went into extra time after 1  -  1 in regular time.
Penance for a slight underweight on Bayern prior to the knock outs. I am still rooting for PSG though.

In the 2019-20 UEFA Champions League, the remaining teams are Bayern Munich (BYM), Paris Saint Germain (PSG), RB Leipzig (RBL) and Lyon (LYN) ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_UEFA_Champions_League#Semi-finals  I will give the initial probability of one of the four teams winning the Champions League as -> 
BYM = PSG = RBL = LYN = 25% = 100% / 4 Of the four remaining teams, only BYM has ever won the Champions League before ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League#Performances_by_club  From the 1956 - 2019 Champions League Finals, I counted 22 times when the winner was a first time winner ->
Champions League Winner in 2020 is a First Time Winner = 34% = 22 / (2019 - 1956 + 1) Given both PSG and LYN have more experience in the Champions League than RBL ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League_clubs_performance_comparison I will give them the majority of the 34% ->
BYM = 66% = 100% - 34%
PSG = 14%
LYN = 17%
RBL = 3% If LYN beats BYM in the Semifinal I will revise my prediction but I believe this to be highly unlikely given their surprising win over Manchester City is being blamed by football commentators on City's Manager ->
https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/53794738

My mentor in forecasting @AnneinAK has one cardinal rule concerning sports betting, I really try to follow here, although I´m german and Munich IS the No1 favorite on this one by far for being the most successful team of all left in the race in the recent past. So let´s get down to facts:
there are 4 teams left, two semifinals and one final only. Soccer/football has some random/luck/ form for the specific day parts in it. The very best team might lose anyway. Look at whom Paris, Lyon and Leipzig got out of the way - dozens of the best teams in Europe, a handful of the top 10 teams in the world among them. Just an example: is someone who kicked out MC really worth much less than the others? They are all cool, the new tournament mode makes it easier for "underdogs" (ridiculous in this context, but you know, what I mean). I consider them almost equal. By the way: I would personally prefer a german final with Leipzig to win... (emotions, no forecast)
I think it’s worth a shot.

Following MC's surprise exit to Lyon, BM are now strong favourites as their path to the final looks easier than it would have against MC, notwithstanding Lyon beating MC. The consensus opinion is that Guardiola once again overthought things and his team selection moved MC away from their 'best' team in an effort to negate a team which, on paper, is inferior.
In the event of an single country final, I cannot see past the 'bigger' side winning. Arguably the best final would be Lyon vs. RB as that seems like a 50-50 matchup.
Man City and Barca now out. This looks like Bayern's to lose.

However, If MC beat Lyon as I expect (3-1 fav) the pace of their forward line could prove a massive threat to a BM team that allowed themselves to be opened up a few times against a dreadful Barca side. MC's relative frailty at the back makes BM favourites, but not massively.

I'm heavily weighting (50%+) the group of teams in the last QF: Real Madrid/Manchester City/Olympique Lyon/Juventus Turin

Real Madrid have to beat MC after losing in the first leg, which isn't going to be easy and their recent form hasn't been great. Ramos also got sent off in their last game, so they will be without their captain. MC have a defense full of holes that won't stand up to the better offenses in the CL, but they also have a relatively easy bracket if they can beat Real Madrid in game 2, so they may be able to coast to an upset in the final. PSG has only played one competitive game in the last few months and their star player was injured in that one fixture. Liverpool, Dortmund, and Ajax are out. Juventus and Barca simply haven't been performing well enough to indicate they have what it takes to win the title, though their stars will always give them a chance. Bayern have a comfortable lead against Chelsea and are firm favorites against any side at the moment so long as rust hasn't set in during their month off.

With a QF draw against PSG followed by a SF against Atletico/RBL, Atalanta have a great opportunity to make the final. Their fearless style of play appears to be well-suited for knockout football. The QF/SF draw makes it tougher for Bayern, and it still feels too soon to judge which of Real Madrid or Man City will go through. Both are in form, but the latter have the advantage.

Forecasted on 2 July. Adjustment made to reflect latest results (i.e. those have been eliminated assigned as 0%, those still in the competition assigned 10% chance - random anchor %). Those in "Another soccer/football club" listed includes Atlanta, Napoli, Lyon and RB Leipzig. % for these are aggregated
Board stroke adjustments:
For those already completed R16 games and progressed increase win %
For those yet to play 2nd leg of R16 and are currently behind decrease win %
For those yet to play 2nd leg of R16 awith away goal advantage increase win % Individual adjustments: 
Factor in amount of important league games remaining. Those with less important league games increase win % (important means their results have impact on placing in league - e.g. Bayern has already won Bundesliga, Man City cannot win title and has advantage over 3rd place).
Factor in this season's head to head record (e.g. Bayern vs Leipzig, PSG vs Lyon). Small increase win % for those with good record if draw so happens (factor in % likelihood to be drawn together) vice versa.
Factor in recent form. Large increase for those with strong form, strong decrease for those with poor form. Those with no recent form (e.g. Lyon and PSG as Ligue 1 cancelled) strong decrease due to lack of match form / preparedness.

Given the postponement of the fixtures due to Covid-19 and the altered schedule for the remaining fixtures it is challenging to judge the form of teams in the build up to the fixtures.  Therefore I would suggest Barcelona and Real Madrid given their remaining domestic schedules would be best placed in the knockout stages
This is assuming the tournament finishes at all, which I put at about 90%

Now they have won the Bundesliga, Bayern have nothing left to play for in the season except the CL. They will have had longest period of all the main rivals to build match fitness and teamwork. Plus they will get a good rest before the quarter finals for which they have almost certainly qualified (with three away goals in the first leg). Too early to say who else has a decent chance until the quarter final draw. Everyone else will fear Bayern. Of the other quarter finalists so far, Athleti and PSG are the best fo the bunch but neither have been great this season.

PSg at a disadvantage with early curtailment of French season Bayern look very strong, I also like Leipzig despite erratic form Barca is they come through the Napoli tie, which they should will be upgraded

Man City have a grudge to bare, Barcelona have had an awful season in terms of internal politics, PSG don't have domestic football. Bayern have started football earlier, a squad of varying ages and talent, haven't succeeded recently but are still on course to win the bundesliga in spite of it being more competitive than any time since 2012.  They will aslo play less matches than City

Winning football matches comes down to scoring more and conceding less. In the champions league knockout stage, ‘where’ you score also matters (away goals rule). Below: Average goals per game - goals conceded per game = difference * opposition so far (0-1) = Performance in Champions league so far… Bayern 3.86-0.71 = 3.15*(0.7) = 2.21
PSG 2.5-0.5 = 2*(0.8) = 1.6
Man. City 2.57-0.71 =1.86*(0.78) = 1.45
Napoli 1.71-0.71 = 1*(0.91) = 0.91
Juventus 1.71-0.71 = 1*(0.72) = 0.72
Atletico 1.5-0.88 = 0.62*(1) = 0.62
Real. Madrid 2.14-1.43 = 0.71*(0.86) = 0.61
Barcelona 1.43-0.71 = 0.72*(0.82) = 0.59
Leipzig 1.75-1 = 0.75*(0.65) = 0.49
Lyon 1.43-1.14 = 0.29*(0.7) = 0.2
Atalanta 2-2 = 0*(0.6) = 0
Chelsea 1.57-1.71 = - 0.14*(0.85) = Very bad. They are most likely out anyway (3-0 down away from home vs Bayern) Teams which still have to make it to the quarter-final are:
Juventus/Lyon (1-0)
MC/Real (2-1)
Bayern/Chelsea (3-0)
Barca/Nap (1-1)
(the first team named is at home for the next leg) COVID-19 is having a huge impact on football. Their form has been taken away and fitness has been reduced. This makes forecasting the winner even more difficult. The German Bundesliga is due to resume on the 16th of May. This will give Bayern a temporary advantage over the others. Injuries to important players have a huge impact on performance. Teams with squad depth will fair better whilst teams who depend on a few players are at more risk, especially if they are injury-prone. Notable mentions… Manchester City has good depth. However, Laporte is injury prone and they perform much worse without him.
PSG has an amazing team but not much depth and dependant on a few key players. An injury to Neymar or Mbappe will lower their chances.  
Bayern has good depth but has been reliant on Lewandowski at times.
Barcelona does not have much depth and relies on a few key players. https://www.oddschecker.com/football/champions-league/winner

Ajax is not in the game anymore. 
Other teams would mean Atalanta, Neapel, Leipzig and Lyon. I do not see them winning the title, even if they make it to the quarter (Neapel, Lyon) and/or semi finals (Atalanta, Leipzig). The competition is too fierce, consistency and frankly, experience matters.  And now, let's try a little kitchen sink psychology here. I expect Chelsea to be eliminated in this round. Same applies to Real Madrid if I'm honest, however, with them you never know. Dortmund has a talented team and PSG does not play consistently. In either case, I don't expect neither Dortmund nor PSG to win the title. I'm indifferent on Atletico and Liverpool. Both are serious contenders if they get to the next round. It's no secret that Liverpool's focus has been on the Premier League, while Atletico is not at its best this season in the Primera Division. Barcelona is not playing well this season, however, I still assume them to get to the next round.  Juventus disappointed against Lyon in the first match of the quarter final but they are still the favorite to get to the next round. Bayern's performance does not need any further description. Manchester City lost the chance to win the Premier League this season so the Champions League represents the competition that they will focus on. Winning against Real Madrid at Bernabeu is impressive.

PSG I have my doubts about their possibility to beat BVB behind closed doors so reducing their %

Unweighted average of forecasts from two sources: 1. Unweighted average of probabilities implied by odds offered by a couple dozen bookmakers, as tracked on oddschecker.com (https://www.oddschecker.com/football/champions-league/winner). I'm using a custom function I wrote in R to scrape that page, clean it up, convert the fractional odds to probabilities, recalibrate them to sum to 1 within bookies, and then average the results. 2. FiveThirtyEight (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/) So, in essence, this is a blend of a large-scale, skin-in-the-game, wisdom-of-crowds forecast with a well-designed ML forecast. In theory, that should be hard to beat. Now let's see how that theory pans out in this instance. My goal is to update weekly.

In the spirit of dragonfly forecasting I am supplementing 538 [1] with betting odds [2]  I am focusing on the betting odds for major teams and adjusting accordingly. Where odds in [2] differ from [1], I average the two weighing [1] by approximately 2/3. Noting major differences:
Barcelona 9% vs 17%
Bayern Munich 19% vs 12% [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/
[2] https://www.oddschecker.com/us/soccer/uefa-champions-league/champions-league/winner
[3] https://www.aceodds.com/bet-calculator/odds-converter.html

Champions league rules allow clubs to acquire up to 3 new players before the start of the next round, Injuries, improved performance, etc., may change odds before the next matches are played. Of the listed sides, a minimum of 4 and a max of 6 can advance to the next round.
Teams 5 and 6 could be Juve and Barca.
Barca (9 GF, 4 GA) vs Napoli (11 GF, 4 GA)
Juve (12 GF, 4 GA) vs Lyon (9 GF, 8 GA) A minimum of 2 "other clubs" (max of 4)  moving on to the next round are either:
Atalanta or Valencia, and
Leipzig or Tottenham
In addition Napoli and Lyon also have a chance to advance. Round of 16 Draw:
Liverpool-Atletico 
PSG-Dortmund
Valencia-Atalanta  -Atalanta 2 wins and a draw in last 3 champ league matches
Leipzig-Tottenham - Tottenham 2 losses, 10 GA in 2 matches against Bayern
Bayern-Chelsea
Barca-Napoli
Juve-Lyon
Man City-R.Madrid

Northern European teams now playing chilly, ugly weather on often damp or rainy pitch that can cause or reaggravate injuries. Another factor is, not all the name clubs "try" to win UEFA, some target other tournaments, which managment, ownershhip and sponsors consider more in their interests. In addition, only English language sources don't give forecasters the big picture. One ought to read Kicker in German, Tutto Sport in Italian, LÉquipe in French. Otherwise the situation is clouded by British football writers.

Socrates is thought to have said "The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing". For sports events, I am guessing that I won't be able to come up with a superior enough theory of the winning team in the short time I have available to forecast on this question. I am betting, however, that by aggregating data-based projections, I can provide some value here (i.e. beat the median of the remaining forecasts).  For now I am using methodology from [1] Probabilities from [2]  [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/methodology/how-our-club-soccer-predictions-work/
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/

The highest predicted clubs are those that have the greatest number of the top players. 
Ajax - Very inexperienced team, lost their main players 
Atletico Madrid - Well coached, not doing as well in their league as the others. Depth of squad is not as good as the other teams 
Barcelona - continuity, have arguably the best player of the generation. 
Bayern - recent coaching change, although in the short term this often provides a boost, this doesn't always translate into winning in competitions exceptions are there DI Matteo and Zidane. 
Chelsea - Inexperience in coach and the the players 
Dortmund - this was more of a guess 
Juventus - best depth in squad and top rated players, lack of true competition in their domestic league does help and mean the payers can be rested
Liverpool - recency  bias would say you cannot discount the champions, they have consistency in the coach and the players. 
Man City - the pressure of the domestic league may have an effect on this 
PSG - some possible disharmony in the squad 
Real Madrid - internal issue with the coach and players.

Liverpool as defending champions are the team to beat. Barcelona will be better defensively and not throw away 3 goal leads. Manchester City have the attacking potential but lack proper central defenders. Juventus and Bayern Munich lack the domestic competition and will find it difficult to compete in the latter stages. Atletico Madrid have lost their best forward and defender but play compact and can definitely pull of an upset.
